items.content_html:
Description

There were some assertions about the legality of hotlinking and copyright which didn't seem quite right/could lead to incorrect conclusions. Revised as to still give good advice about hotlinking and copyright without conflating the two and without making statements about what is/is not legal.

Motivation

If we're going to assert that Hotlinking is bad, we should have solid reasoning (like, it uses bandwidth that isn't ours). Copyright issues are important as well, but we shouldn't mix them up with hotlinking. Separating the two makes for more solid statements about both.

Additional details

Also made a PR for hotlinking in the glossary.

Related issues and pull requests

Fixes #22039
items.title: Revised warnings about Hotlinking.

items.content_html:
Description

This page stated that hotlinking causes copyright concerns. However, in a weird way, hotlinking actually might avoid copyright concerns by linking to it instead of hosting copyrighted content directly. Better just to say hotlinking is frowned upon because of the bandwidth usage without permission.

Motivation

Hotlinking probably should be considered unethical, but we should have correct statements about why (bandwidth usage) rather than iffy/incorrect ones (copyright).

Related issues and pull requests

Relates to #22039
items.title: Update hotlink glossary page

items.content_html:
Description

Normal
Required

In the above code you can see the required attribute has value "required" which is not always necessary to work, providing only required attribute is sufficient.

I have tried it worked absolutely fine without value, though we can give value to be consistence.

In input element required attribute not compulsory need to have value "required" to be required. Only giving required attribute works absolutely fine without value.

Motivation

It's a small thing i have found which needs to be cleared i thought. Correct me if i am wrong.

Additional details

Related issues and pull requests

items.content_html:
Description

This PR does some cleaning to the https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/PerformanceObserver pages.

Motivation

openwebdocs/project#62

Additional details

  • "frame" is no more a thing. Removed it from examples.
  • Examples sections are always in the form of: h2-"Examples" -> h3-myExample followed by a description and the code.
  • minor formatting and line wrapping fixes
  • The observe method now has two examples, one for watching multiple event types, one for observing just one.

Related issues and pull requests

None.
items.title: Cleanup PerformanceObserver pages

items.content_html:
Description

Add documentation for all methods of the MutationRecord interface which do not exist at present.

Documented with examples

  • addedNodes()
  • attributeName()
  • nextSibling()
  • oldValue()
  • previousSibling()
  • removedNodes()
  • target()
  • type()

Without examples

  • attributeNamespace()

Motivation

Working on a project that relies heavily on MutationObserver and manipulation of nodes leveraging MutationRecord; the documentation regarding MutationRecord was not useful. Decided to pause working on my project to flesh out the public documentation on the interface and its methods.

This is my first PR to a public project. Please let me know if I screwed up somewhere.
items.title: Add MutationRecord methods

items.content_html: it was missing
items.title: added ::marker to generated content

items.content_html:
FF107 ships the contain-intrinsic-* CSS properties, which means that with Chrome existing support the properties are no longer experimental. This removes the tags and compat macro.

In addition, it adds trivial (and repetitive) examples with cross link to the more full example from the long hand to shorthand cases. My understanding is that where possible a trivial example is better than no example. There is not much benefit here to creating a bigger example than the one in the contain-intrinsic-size topic.

Other docs work for this can be tracked in #21274
items.title: CSS contain-intrinsic-* not experimental and add examples

items.content_html:

The original issue is resolved, in my opinion, it's clear that this page references the reading material needed to complete the assessment. In this case, I'm doing some minor rewording to simplify.

Fixes #11058
items.title: chore(docs) minor refresh on math skills test page

items.content_html:
Description

In Safari the example doesn’t render correctly if either or both of these are true:

  1. there is whitespace between the opening <p> tag and the opening quotation mark,
  2. “dumb” quotation marks are used (" rather than “/”).

This fixes both.

Motivation

Allow documentation reader see hanging-punctuation in action.

Additional details

To clarify, while the example for hanging-punctuation before this PR may have been technically correct, minor formatting details prevented all users (including those on Safari Technical Preview) from seeing the property in action.

  1. The spec seems to assert that the ‘dumb’ quote " should hang, too, and makes no mention of leading/trailing whitespace.
  2. However, Safari requires it to be a proper quote (“) and leading whitespace would prevent hanging.

Thus it’s an open question whether this should be fixed or Safari should be fixed.

Related issues and pull requests
items.title: fix(css): `hanging-punctuation` sample

items.content_html:
The existing example uses polling every 300 millis, it's noted in the linked issue that we can use eventListeners instead.

Notes:
This example could be improved in general as we're using an iframe, so we might not even need to open a new window. We have the demonstrated effect by clicking inside the iframe and the embedding document.

Fixes #10312
items.title: chore(docs) change example to use eventListener instead of polling
